title: How to Caulk a Bathroom Sink

steps.title: Wipe a clean cloth around the edge of the bathroom sink and the counter it rests on.
steps.content: Wipe a clean cloth around the edge of the bathroom sink and the counter it rests on. Make sure the area is clean and dry and has no dust or debris to get in the way of the caulk.

steps.title: Remove any old caulk from the edge of the sink with a sharp utility knife.
steps.content: Remove any old caulk from the edge of the sink with a sharp utility knife. Caulk is a soft material that cuts easily and stretches when pulled. [1] X Research source You can also remove caulk with a special tool. It is typically plastic and has a little pointy thing on it that helps you pull the caulk out. It is usually available in a painting section of a home improvement store.

steps.title: Cut away the old caulk where it meets the counter and the sink's rim.
steps.content: Cut away the old caulk where it meets the counter and the sink's rim. Pull the caulk free from the sink and counter. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Use denatured alcohol to clean up any leftover caulk.
steps.content: Use denatured alcohol to clean up any leftover caulk.

steps.title: Let the sink's rim dry completely and ensure no water has seeped into the crack.
steps.content: Let the sink's rim dry completely and ensure no water has seeped into the crack.

steps.title: Use a utility knife to cut the tip off the tube of caulk at a 45-degree angle.
steps.content: Use a utility knife to cut the tip off the tube of caulk at a 45-degree angle. Cut just enough of the tip off to allow the caulk to fill the gap next to the rim; cutting away too much of the tip will mean too much caulk on your counter.

steps.title: Insert the end of the caulk tube into a caulk gun and push the plunger of the gun into the back of the tube.
steps.content: Insert the end of the caulk tube into a caulk gun and push the plunger of the gun into the back of the tube. Squeeze the trigger lightly to prime the tube.

steps.title: Hold the caulk tube at a 45-degree angle to the sink's rim where it meets the counter top.
steps.content: Hold the caulk tube at a 45-degree angle to the sink's rim where it meets the counter top. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Squeeze the caulk tube gently until a continuous line of caulk fills the gap around the rim completely.
steps.content: Squeeze the caulk tube gently until a continuous line of caulk fills the gap around the rim completely. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Wet your index finger with water and gently smooth the caulk against the side of the sink's rim and the counter top to completely seal the gap.
steps.content: Wet your index finger with water and gently smooth the caulk against the side of the sink's rim and the counter top to completely seal the gap.

steps.title: When you are happy with the results, insert a small screw into the tip to seal the tube of caulk, so you can use it again in your next project.
steps.content: When you are happy with the results, insert a small screw into the tip to seal the tube of caulk, so you can use it again in your next project.

steps.title: Let the caulk cure for at least 24 hours before using the sink.
steps.content: Let the caulk cure for at least 24 hours before using the sink.
